title: #ReadMyLips: Proof the President's "Grab Them By The Pussy" Comments Haven't Been Forgotten
text: View on Instagram "By having the statue as this shape, it empowers women to be proud of their sexuality and bodies," said Michelle Wen, the Cornell organizer, in a statement about the project. "Women have nothing to hide; We only have our determination, spirit, and strong minds to be proud of." #ReadMyLips began as a grassroots initiative on college campuses, including Cornell, Yale, NYU, Brown, Georgetown, and Oxford. Students passionate about holding their government accountable to the rights of its people began sharing their messages on Mogul, and inspired by the budding movement, Mogul minted #ReadMyLips, collecting millions of letters, poems, songs and messages to deliver right to Trump’s doorstep. "The #ReadMyLips campaign is hugely important, not just in representing women across America, but in representing women across the world," Oxford organizer Sasha Skovron said in a statement. “Through this movement, we can send a message loud and clear: nobody has the right to deny a woman the freedom to make decisions over her own body. President Trump poses a great threat to this freedom, and so whether an American citizen or not, #ReadMyLips stands for women everywhere." More women's activism in the news:
